awd_abstract_narration:
Each year, hundreds of thousands of migrants in the U.S. are deported to their countries of origin as a consequence of criminal violations. What happens when these migrants return to their native countries? Many criminal deportees, having been raised in the U.S., are unfamiliar with their homeland's language, history, and social customs. Furthermore, criminal deportees can face the prejudices of fellow citizens who suspect them of bringing crime and delinquent behavior into the country. These factors can present challenges as deportees attempt to resettle after deportation. Yet at the same time, deportees have often learned English, attended school, and learned marketable skills during their time in the U.S., which can lead to employment and status in their countries of origin. With a pending rise in criminal deportations, it is essential to identify the opportunities and obstacles encountered by deportees, and the services and resources that would assist their resettlement. Dr. Kivland of Dartmouth College and her team will conduct a longitudinal ethnography of deportation, following the a cohort of deportees over the first three years of the resettlement process. Findings will be disseminated to organizations and individuals that influence policy debates related to migration. The project also broadens participation of underrepresented groups in science, and provides opportunities for training undergraduate and graduate students in STEM fields. The project builds capacity and infrastructure through the broadening of international scientific cooperation.
  
The research will be conducted in Haiti, where Dr. Kivland has conducted research since 2006 and has extensive knowledge of political and social conditions. Haiti is a is an ideal research site because it has recently witnessed a dramatic rise in its deportee population. In 2016, it received 310 deportees; in 2017, this number rose to 5,578 deportees. Haiti is also an important research setting because it provides an opportunity to study a racial subgroup rarely analyzed in deportation studies. Whereas several studies have analyzed the criminalization and stigmatization that Latino deportees face in Latin American countries, there has been less research on the experiences of Afro-descendant deportees in the Caribbean. This study hypothesizes that Haitian deportees' experiences are particularly shaped by their Black racial identity. Preliminary research suggests that Haitian deportees may confront the prejudices of fellow Haitians who suspect them of violence, crime, and what it perceived as a disreputable African American culture. But they may also capitalize on their racial identity and American cultural capital to find employment, status, and community in Haiti. Working with a team of Haiti-based graduate students and U.S.-based undergraduate students, Dr. Kivland will chronicle the everyday successes and challenges that deportees face in their attempts to rebuild lives in Haiti. Using the ethnographic methods of observation, participant observation, and interviews, the team will analyze how deportees' racial identity, deportee status, migration history, and other emergent factors shape their resettlement trajectories in positive and negative ways. Findings from this research will lead to a fuller understanding of the societal factors and personal circumstances that lead to deportation, the difficulties and prospects people face once deported, and the resources that would assist deportees in the resettlement process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Thousands of Haitian asylum seekers subjected to forced repatriation by the United States have faced a difficult time reintegrating in an unstable country which some of them hardly know. Adding to the difficulties are the prevalence of street gangs in Haiti and common assumptions that deportees are linked to organized crime. The major goal of this project has been to identify the opportunities and obstacles encountered by deportees, and the services and resources that would assist their resettlement. Our research has yielded a deeper understanding of the sociocultural factors that influence the experience of deportation and resettlement.  

This project has spanned 5 years, 2018-2023. In year one, the then-primary researcher traveled to three detention facilities in the United States to interview participants facing deportation hearings, as well as contacting family members by phone. Two research trips to Haiti enabled interviews with recently deported individuals and participant observation at their places of residence and work. These trips also enabled the researcher to form and train the Haiti-based research assistant team.  

In years two through five, this team continued to contribute to the research agenda laid out initially, conducting interviews with deportees and representatives of social sectors involved in deportation in Haiti. Research assistants reported findings to the primary researcher each month. In year two, the primary researcher assembled a team of undergraduate research assistants to organize and code data collected by the Haiti-based team. The primary researcher also trained these undergraduate assistants in interviewing. Alongside the primary researcher, they conducted interviews with Haitian migrants, immigration attorneys, and immigrant advocates. In year four, a postdoctoral research associate joined the team to help coordinate the research team and support writing.

Between years two and three, the team found that their initial hypotheses surrounding the influential role of race in shaping deportation experiences had proven accurate. Many deportees had reflected in interviews on their experiences with racism in Haiti. They identified these experiences as related to their affiliations with American Blackness. Association with a Black American racial identity has a complicated influence on deportees: some were able to use this identity to enable commercial artistic success, while many others attributed their difficulty finding work with prejudices against deportees as gang members.

Throughout the project, the primary researcher guided the Haiti-based team alongside the Dartmouth College-based team in conducting interviews, collecting data, and compiling archives of news media and other relevant historical information. She also taught undergraduate and graduate students about anthropological research, immigration and deportation, and Haiti in multiple locations, using the methods and materials developed in this project. Due to the coronavirus pandemic, the project’s execution changed dramatically, shifting to a remote-video enabled rhythm of team meetings and data collection. Research assistants in Haiti became, as a result, even more central to the project than they had already been. 

This research has uncovered the ways deportees’ affiliations with American Blackness—a socially prized yet stigmatized racialization—serve as the basis for and the means to contest marginalization as deportees in Haitian society. Those who are deported from the United States (deportees, or in Haitian Kreyol, depòte) must grapple with the prejudices of many Haitians who suspect them of bringing crime into the country. Findings indicate deportees face challenges in trying to find employment, housing, schooling, and social connections. 

The researchers have previously documented the politics involved in naming street organizations in Haiti. This project has found that deportees work with social and political processes of criminalization and racialization as they make a life in a society that both reveres and fears them. The distinction between groups associated with criminality, self-interest, and violence, on the one hand, and groups with a social mission and orientation to popular empowerment, on the other, looms large. This distinction is an important finding in the context of the landscape of political violence in Haiti. It reveals the impacts of transnational processes of racialization and criminalization of Blackness on people whose lives have been shaped by natural disaster, voluntary and forced migration, economic and political instability in more than two nations.

Everything about deportation is political, though the mobilizing of the forces that control or contest it may not be overt or even spoken. This work reveals the possibilities and limitations of politically mobilizing against deportation - it also reveals the effect of mobilization, or it's absence, on the experiences of deportees.  

Tales of exploitation figure large in the publications that have emerged and will emerge from this research, but exploitation is also not the whole story. The participants in this study show us the complexity of the deportee identity. Although not easy, the deportation experience can be repurposed by its bearers toward new and surprising ends—ends that challenge us to both reaffirm the humanity of the deported and to treat them more humanely. 


Last Modified: 01/08/2025
Modified by: Charis F Boke
